title: 114_hr4996
content:
The "Sensible Estate Tax Act of 2016" is cited in this section. It proposes returning estate and gift tax to 2009 levels by amending the rate schedule in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tentative tax rates based on different income brackets are as follows:
- Not over $10,000: 18% of the amount
- Over $10,000 but not over $20,000: $1,800 plus 20% of the excess over $10,000
- Over $20,000 but not over $40,000: $3,800 plus 22% of the excess over $20,000
- Over $40,000 but not over $60,000: $8,200 plus 24% of the excess For incomes over $60,000 but not over $80,000, the tax is $13,000 plus 26% of the excess over $60,000. For incomes over $80,000 but not over $100,000, the tax is $18,200 plus 28% of the excess over $80,000. For incomes over $100,000 but not over $150,000, the tax is $23,800 plus 30% of the excess over $100,000. For incomes over $150,000 but not over $250,000, the tax is $38,800 plus 32% of the excess over $150,000. For incomes over $250,000 but not over $500,000, the tax is $70,800 plus 34% of the excess over $250,000. For incomes over $500,000 but not over $750,000, the tax is $155,800 plus 37% of the excess over $500,000. For incomes over $750,000 but not over $1,000,000, the tax is $248,300 plus 39% of the excess. For incomes over $1,000,000, the tax is $345,800 plus 41% of the excess over $1,000,000. For incomes over $1,250,000, the tax is $448,300 plus 43% of the excess over $1,250,000. For incomes over $1,500,000, the tax is $555,800 plus 45% of the excess over $1,500,000. The basic exclusion amount for estate tax purposes is $3,500,000. There are modifications to the deceased spousal unused exclusion amount in the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment modifies the deceased spousal unused exclusion amount for a surviving spouse, setting it at $1,000,000 or the applicable exclusion amount of the decedent reduced by the tentative tax on the estate. Effective after December 31, 2016.
